title: Section 184 - Driving dangerously
text: Whoever drives a motor vehicle at a speed or in a manner which is dangerous to the public shall be punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees or both.

title: Section 420 - Cheating
text: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Preamble - Constitution of India (summary)
text: The Preamble declares India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic and aims to secure justice, liberty, equality and fraternity for all citizens.

title: Article 12 - Definition of State
text: Article 12 defines the term 'State' to include the Government and Parliament of India, the Government and Legislature of each State, and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: Article 14 - Equality before law
text: Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of the laws to all persons within the territory of India, prohibiting arbitrariness in state action.

title: Article 15 - Prohibition of discrimination
text: Article 15 prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth and allows the State to make special provisions for women, children and socially and educationally backward classes.

title: Article 16 - Equality of opportunity in public employment
text: Article 16 provides equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters of public employment and allows reservation for backward classes as permitted by the Constitution.

title: Article 19 - Freedoms of speech and expression etc.
text: Article 19 guarantees certain fundamental freedoms including freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence and profession, subject to reasonable restrictions in the interest of public order, security and morality.

title: Article 21 - Protection of life and personal liberty
text: Article 21 states that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law; courts have interpreted this broadly to include many rights essential to dignity and fair process.

title: Article 25 - Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and propagation of religion
text: Article 25 guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality and health and other provisions of Part III.

title: Article 32 - Right to constitutional remedies
text: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights and empowers the Court to issue writs for protection of those rights.

title: Directive Principles of State Policy (overview)
text: Directive Principles set out the policy directions for the State to establish social and economic democracy; they are non-justiciable but guide legislation and governance to promote welfare and social justice.

title: Fundamental Duties (overview)
text: Fundamental Duties, added by the 42nd Amendment, list the moral obligations of citizens to uphold the Constitution, respect national symbols, and promote harmony and public spirit.

title: Article 368 - Amendment procedure
text: Article 368 prescribes the procedure for amendment of the Constitution, distinguishing between amendments that require a simple parliamentary majority and those requiring ratification by states.

title: Article 246 - Distribution of legislative powers
text: Article 246, together with the Seventh Schedule, divides legislative subjects between Parliament and State Legislatures into Union List, State List and Concurrent List.

title: Article 356 - Provisions in case of failure of constitutional machinery in states
text: Article 356 authorizes the President to impose President's Rule in a state if the constitutional machinery fails; this power is subject to judicial review and safeguards.

title: Independent Judiciary (principle)
text: The Constitution establishes an independent judiciary with the Supreme Court at the apex and High Courts in states; judicial independence and impartiality are core constitutional values.

title: Judicial review (overview)
text: Judicial review empowers courts to examine the constitutionality of legislative and executive actions and to strike down laws or acts that contravene the Constitution or fundamental rights.

title: Article 50 - Separation of judiciary from executive
text: Article 50 requires the State to take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State, to ensure impartial administration of justice.

title: Article 74 - Council of Ministers to aid and advise President
text: Article 74 provides for a Council of Ministers headed by the Prime Minister to aid and advise the President in exercising his functions, reflecting responsible government.

title: Article 368A and special amendment notes (historical)
text: Certain amendments and their judicial review history are notable; the basic structure doctrine limits Parliament's power to amend core constitutional features.

title: Election Commission (role)
text: The Election Commission is an independent constitutional authority responsible for conduct and supervision of free and fair elections to Parliament, State Legislatures and the offices of President and Vice-President.

title: Federalism and Centre-State relations (overview)
text: India's Constitution establishes a quasi-federal system where powers are divided between the Centre and States, with mechanisms for cooperation and central intervention in certain circumstances.

title: Article 311 - Protection against dismissal, removal or reduction in rank
text: Article 311 provides safeguards for civil servants against arbitrary dismissal or removal, requiring inquiry and procedural fairness in disciplinary action by the State.

title: Fundamental Rights - Overview
text: Fundamental Rights (Part III) guarantee civil and political liberties such as equality, freedom of speech, life and personal liberty, freedom of religion, cultural and educational rights, and protection from exploitation.

title: Article 300A - Right to property (constitutional perspective)
text: After constitutional amendments, the right to property ceased to be a fundamental right but remains a legal right under Article 300A, protecting individuals from deprivation of property without due process.

title: Special Provisions for SC/ST and Backward Classes
text: The Constitution provides for special measures, including reservation in education and public employment and legislative safeguards, to uplift Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and other backward classes.
